item.description:
No Benefits is a card game about your job. The job you’d quit in four months, five years ago. Relive one week of your life in one hour.

Remember how you said you wanted to be a writer? An artisanal pickle maker? Now's your chance. It only takes you two hours to finish your data entry, but management doesn't know that. Do you really want to make copies of copies all day? Why not work on your novel and brine pickles in the bathroom instead? You’re pulling a paycheck either way. At the end of the day, players that didn't complete their tasks will be reprimanded, unless of course they can play an excuse to get out of it. Watch out for Wednesday, though, as there's always something that goes wrong on hump day.


No Benefits is set in an average workplace, where players are average employees trying to get through the daily grind. You need to balance not getting fired with working too hard, in order to finish the week as the least productive worker.

The goal of the game is to gain the most slack by the end of the 5 day working week (5 turns).

Each turn, players will be given an assignment from the day's inbox by the current Assistant Manager. On Wednesdays, crisis cards are also drawn and dealt with. Players can then play morning memos, plan their workday by selecting Grind cards to play, and then revealing their selected cards to show their progress towards their assignments. Players with incomplete assignments can plead their case with excuse cards. Without an excuse, players receive a write-up, and are fired if they gain 3. Finally, any late memos are resolved and that round's slack scores are tallied up.

The game involves a careful balance between putting off work for points, or doing work to gain sway and perks from your superiors.

item.description:
Translated from the German introduction:

"Dear parents, Ich spiele Einkaufen shall support children playfully to develop a better understanding of the numbers and quantities from 1-5. The vocabulary can be expanded as well. For this discuss all items on the shopping lists and the names of the shops repeatedly. Since there are regional differences in naming the goods and shops just use the one most appropriate to you."


Ich spiele Einkaufen is a children's game which shall help to develop competence in the number range 1-5. Each player is given a list with 5 different items on it in 5 different amounts (1-5) which need to be gathered from 5 different shops.

The game map shows the different shops (3 times each) as well as a supermarket where you can get every good and 3 spots without any action. A 6 sided die numbered from 1-4 (1&2 are doubled) is rolled and the number is advanced on the shops track around the board.

If the player ends on a shop where he needs some good from he can claim it by naming the good and the amount of it (e.g. "I take 5 sausages from the butchery"). The player then picks the needed item token from the map and places it on his/her shopping list. The first player to collect all 5 items from the shopping list wins.

item.description:
Krackades is a wild party game where you compete against the clock and each other to Act, Draw, or Sculpt (playdoh included) the most outrageous and irreverent things imaginable!

Players have 60 seconds to Act, Draw or Sculpt a wild phrase. To win teammates must guess 3 cards in each section before the other team.

However, the opposing team doesn't sit idly by -- they can choose to trip up the other team's success by using special cards called Krack Attacks! The first team to correctly guess enough cards wins.

Brunan is a party game. Players are old heroes that gather in an old tavern to remember their former lives as heroes. The active player has to tell an adventure they all lived together and challenge the other players. There are five types of challenges:
- dexterity (throw dice on the tavern map)
- physical and mental fights (dice-resolved)
- memory (remember a list of words, usually directions)
- auctions to buy a object or guessing a secret code to open the safe where it's kept
- acting (mime)

Players who successfully complete one of these activities wins a card on which a certain amount of money is indicated. At the end of the game, the player with the most money wins the game.

Players are doing development aid by founding projects (water, hospital, farming, school) in provinces of Tanzania. Winner is the player who has founded all his projects first.

Game consists of:
1 game board,
6 pawns (jeeps),
1 dice,
72 project chips,
6 flying tickets,
40 chance cards,
15 hazard cards,
and game money (Tanzanian shillings)

In Construction Site, you and your friends are builders. You have received the plans for the buildings you will construct and you have ordered the materials you will need to build. However, there has been a mix-up. Instead of receiving the materials you asked for, you get random shipments delivered at regular intervals. You and your fellow builders must team up to sort through the mess, selling what materials you can to pay for the materials you need before time runs out!

One to four players must follow Blueprint cards and play Material cards to build the structures on the Blueprints before the deck runs out.

Players have to "pay" for any Materials that they play by discarding other cards from their hands or removing cards from the Material deck. When a Blueprint is completed, players earn a reward, which is to return some cards from the discard pile to the Material deck.

Construction Site fits in a small box that fits in your pocket, containing all necessary components to play.

His father's name was Celtillus, of a noble family and a chief of the Averni tribe of Gauls--a people with a remarkably sophisticated civilization and tradition as warriors and craftsmen, but fiercely resistant toward having a ruler at beyond the tribal level. Celtillus tried to assert authority to organize and ally the disparate tribes against Roman incursions, but tradition and habit were against him and he was killed by his own people. But strife with Rome worsened, and his son elected to try again for tribal unification to survive against the two threats of voracious Rome and ambitious Julius Caesar. The son negotiated, inspired, made alliances, and finally took on the traditional title of "supreme warlord" that his father had died reaching for.

That title was "Vercingetorix," and he bore the title so well that people today think of it as his name (which we do not know). But then, no Gaul ever bore the title again. Maybe you can change that.

ATO #44 offers Vercingetorix: Twilight of the Gauls, a new game by designer Richard Berg, that challenges players to unify Gaul in around the 1st Century B.C. from 2-4 players compete for power in all three of the main Gallic areas. The Romans and Germans are NOT active players, but introduced with random and temporary control to interfere with active player intentions. Players draw chits each turn to improve their holdings, begin campaigns, or obtain more tribal allies. Or, they may draw surprising "Opportunities" that allow them to interfere with other players' turns and even launch revolts that could suppress Roman activities and elevate player esteem. Game length varies with number of players, but most games will last 2-3 hours.

The choice is yours. Can you make the title "Vercingetorix" your own?

Doraemon is a robotic cat featured in a Japanese comic/animation series of the same title. The game comes with 5 Doraemon figures and 6 sets of 5 cards of the same color.

When you play, you take Doraemon figures, one less then there are players, and put them in the middle where everybody can reach them. You take as many sets of colored cards as there are players. You shuffle all these cards and give each player 5. Then everybody passes one of his cards at the same moment to his right hand neighbor. When a player has a set of 5 cards of the same color, he grabs a Doraemon figure and calls out 'Doraemon'. Then the remaining player have to grab one of the remaining Doraemon figures as fast as possible. The player who wasn't able to grab one, gets 1 minus point.

As soon as 1 player has 3 minus points, he loses, while all the other players win.

Object: To be the first player to reach his or her Treasure X near the center of the gameboard.

For 2 - 4 players

Ages 7 - 12

Contents: 24 cards, 4 playing pieces, spinner and gameboard

Intelligensspillet Investor is an intelligence game with endless possibilities. It has to work formåk entertaining and educational. The rules and procedures of the game are broadly the same as those used in everyday life when you place (invisterer) money in real estate or mortgages.

The purpose of the game is to buy properties (there are 12 houses to choose from), pay out your mortgage - and avoid bankrupcy and foreclosure!
The game mechanism is a roulette with 12 (six large and six small) tiles - divided into five options;
 - H: The six large green ones where you have to pay the rent for your house(s)
 - D: One red where you pay taxes for roads and sewers
 - S: Two reds where you pay Property Tax
 - T: Two reds where you have to pay mortgage
 - ?: Black where you have to pay out the last loan of the house.
Every player spin the wheel for EVERY property (s)he owns - if (s) owns more than one it is needed to state which house there is on spin.

If a player can't pay up and can't get money by other means the house will be set on auction.
The profit will go to the bankrupt seller.

The game is over after an agreed time, where every player sells there propertied back to the bank (they will get the price in the deed MINUS the eventually debt). The winner will be the one with most profit - or least loss.

Designed by real estate broker Aage Eliasen, Copenhagen

name.value: Armored Knights: Guderian Crosses the Desna 1941

item.description:
Guderian Crosses the Desna 1941 takes you to the place where Guderian made his turn to the south and started the encirclement of Kiev. Two of his Panzer Divisions, 3rd and 4th, attempted to take the major bridge over the Desna River by a Coup de Main. After failing the Germans make a more deliberate attempt the next day and the fate of the Soviet Armies at Kiev is sealed.

The game has units built as Battalions for Infantry, Armor, and Artillery. Supporting arms such as Recon, anti-tank, anti-aircraft, engineer, and military intelligence are built as companies. These supporting arms units are used to multiply the combat strength of the battalions. The system uses a variable strength table that eliminates gaming the system for a few extra strength points. Players will find that combined arms are the ticket to success.

This game makes an excellent introduction to the Armored Knights game system. It is small and yet challenging. Once you learn the basics of calculating strengths things move along nicely.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 2-4 hours
Hex: 1.24 miles / 2.0 kilometers
Units: Company to Battalion

Game Inventory:
Four 11 x 17" full color mapsheets
One dual-side printed countersheet (216 1/2" counters)
One 26-page Guderian Crosses the Desna 1941 rulebook
Three scenario setup charts
Nine Player Aid Cards
Two 10-sided dice
One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-15 hours

2 player game, played on the spaces of a 7x7 board.

One player plays black the other white.

2 pawns, black and white.
A supply of black and white stackable pieces.

THE WIN – There are two ways to win, one way is if on your turn you manage to form an unbroken orthogonally adjacent path, connecting your pawn, your stacks and your opponent’s pawn. The second way is if you control the most stacks of 4 pieces high at endgame.

STACK - A stack is one or more pieces of either color.
The color of the stack's top piece determines its owner (e.g., a black top piece makes it a black stack).

Stacks cannot be greater than 4 pieces high.
Stacks of 4 pieces high cannot move.
Stacks cannot split.

MOVEMENT – Pawns start out on base tiles on opposite corners of the board and move along the outer edge of the board. Pawns may move to any point along either side of the board, so long as they do not jump over their opponent's pawn and so long as they do not occupy the same side of the board between base tiles.

Stacks move orthogonally along empty spaces(no jumps).

Stacks move equal to the number of pieces within the stack. (e.g. , a stack of 1 moves one space, a stack of 2 moves two spaces and a stack of 3 moves three spaces.)

Board starts out empty, then pawns are placed on the base tiles.

TURN - Black moves first, turn then alternates.

On each turn, each player must take one of the following actions, which constitutes a valid move:

•Move your pawn and drop a single piece onto any empty point that lies between your pawn and the target point as long as all the points between your pawn and your target point are also empty or
•Move your pawn and drop a single piece on top of a friendly or enemy stack that is less than 4 high, also the stack most be in line of sight of your pawn and any stacks in-between your pawn and the target stack must have less pieces than the target stack, or
•Move your pawn and then move one of your stacks.

The game ends when neither player can make a valid move on their turn.

The images and story for the game include the most famous tight rope walker of the time, Blondin.

Charles Blondin is famous for first walking across Niagara Falls Gorge on a tight rope in 1859. He would later walk across numerous other times and entertain the crowds by crossing blindfolded, on stilts, or with his manager on his back.

Game board shows an amusing scene with a tight rope stretched across a river flowing down from a waterfall. Directions for the game state ‘Ben’, who stands on the cliff dressed in the sailor suit has already crossed safely. The four walkers still attempting to get to the other side by way of the rope are named Ez, Uncle Tom, Fatty Fisk, and ‘the expert Blondin’.

The game board also shows people falling from the tight rope and landing in the water below. These are named in the directions too. Ebenezer is tumbling into the water, only Nebuchasnezzar’s feet are shown as he sinks below the water, Ezekiel is swimming to shore, and Jeremiah is said to be going up the ladder.

The boat in the scene is named as well. Commanded by Uncle Sam and carrying a small African-American boy, the boat represents the Freedmen’s Bureau. This agency was created in 1865 to help the newly freed slaves. With the tight rope bridging the gap, and the dangers of failing, the game is seen to give subtle references to the post civil war era.

Tight Rope is played by the spinning the indicator (earlier edition - rolling the two dice).

To step on the rope (place his piece on space 1), a player must spin a 1. To move across to number 12, a player must then spin the next number to where his piece rests. This is done by spinning two times in a row. If a player does not spin the number needed to move his piece one step ahead, the player then moves down the grid. Whenever he spin the number needed (no matter how far down the grid he is), he moves to the number near the rope. If the player does not spin the needed number and is in the last space below his numbered step, he moves back one step.

The first player across wins!

Typical race spin and move game. First player, who cross 77 stations (24 of them are numbered) wins the game.
Game board is on the bottom of the box.

Who can guide the frogs to the pond? In 1, 2, Hüpferei!, two kids try to walk frogs to the pond by rolling a die. The die determines whether the frog moves one or two spaces, and the player whose frog first reaches the pond wins.

Included in 1, 2, Hüpferei! are an extra die and rules for a more advanced game.

link.value: HABA My Very First Games series

item.description:
Deck Hockey is a Co-Operative game that replicate a Street Hockey game. Team up to be the ones who finish the 3rd period with the most goals scored and win.

Played 2vs2 or in team (3vs3, 4vs4, 5vs5)Deck Hockey is a family game. Designed to be played by all member of your family and kids, you will enjoy "break sticks", play "the trap", get the "Momentum" and carefully use your Slap Shot.

Players are places around the table so they have an opponent at their right and one at their left. One full deck represent one period and the game have 3 periods.

The "ice" is represented by 5 cards places on a table. 1 neutral zone, 1 red zone, 1 blue zone, a red and a blue goalie. A puck with 2 sided coloured (Blue and red obviously) serves to mark the progression of the puck on the ice. The puck will advance from zone to zone up to the goalie where you can attempt a shot... if the opposing team do not intercept first.

As the game start each players will draw 6 cards from the deck. In this deck are the shot cards, pass cards, interception cards and save cards. The deck also contain a series of number cards from 1 to 8 (6 of each). If your team has the control of the puck, you can pass or shot by playing the right card. if not you can intercept or have to attempts saves if you opponent shoots on you.

2 piles are set for the played cards on the table. One for the action cards and on for the numbered cards. The numbered cards mostly works the same way as the action cards: If you can match from you hand the numbered card on top of the "Number pile", you create an action. If your team has the control of the puck, you create a pass or shot and if you dont you can intercept or attempts make the save if you opponent shoots on you.

A set of card in the deck serves as interaction between players to add more reality to the game and to give you an edge on your opponents. The Brocken Stick, The Trap, The Time Out, The Momentum, etc.

J.F.K.'s "Just For Kicks New Frontier Game" is based on President John F. Kennedy, family and politics.

Game play: roll the dice, move exact spaces, take a card and follow the instructions written on them.

The object of the game is to reach the White House before your opponents. The first player to enter the White House wins and is President; 2nd - Attorney General; 3rd - Secretary of State and the last one becomes Vice President.

Games pieces include:
1 dice
4 tokens (white token is the PT-109, red token is a bottle of scotch, blue token is a football and the silver token is a cracked spaceship)
20 Brownies Ye Olde Apple Polish cards
20 Boner cards
1 game board 18 7/8" X 18 7/8".

Diez Negritos (translated as And Then There Were None) is a cooperative board game based on the Agatha Christie novel of the same name. In this game, players take control of a group of characters isolated in a mansion on a lonely island. The characters start getting murdered one after another, and players need to make groups with the characters and send them to different locations, either in the mansion or on the island, in order to discover clues and disclose the identity of the murderer.

Players decide when to take advantage of each character's ability and cards, in addition to guessing who is necessary and who is dispensable. Ideally you'll reveal the killer's identity before time runs out — but not all of the players are what they seem to be and the murderer may have an unsuspected accomplice amongst your group.

Will you be able to cooperate and unmask the killer and his accomplice before the last of the characters dies?


Diez Negritos es un juego cooperativo basado en la novela homónima de Agatha Christie. En él tomaremos el control de un grupo de personajes aislados en una mansión de una solitaria isla. Poco a poco los asesinatos se irán sucediendo y deberemos ponernos de acuerdo para formar grupos con los 10 personajes y enviarlos a los distintos emplazamientos disponibles, tanto en la mansión como en la isla, para desvelar las pistas y así revelar la identidad del asesino.

Tendréis que aprovechar la habilidad y las cartas de cada personaje, decidir cuales serán necesarias y cuales prescindibles y, con un poco de suerte, lograréis revelar la identidad del culpable antes de que se agote el tiempo. ¡Pero cuidado! No todos los jugadores son lo que parecen y tal vez el asesino tenga un cómplice insospechado entre vosotros...

¿Seréis capaces de cooperar y descubrir al asesino y su cómplice antes de que muera el último de los personajes?

item.description:
It's a roll and move game about fowarding pawns across a 50 boxes path with many traps and short-cuts. Its theme is about a persecution of a dangerous gangster, called "Mr. Kill" and his exotic gang.

The game was a board made with collectible stickers as a promotional resource of a Chilean Gas Station Company (COPEC) in year 1988.

War in the Pacific is a board game set in the armed conflict that took place from 1879 to 1883 in which Peru and Bolivia fought against Chile, for 2, 3 or 4 players of ages 8 and older. There are two sides for which you can play: the alliance of Peru and Bolivia or Chile .

The goal is to achieve 10 victory points or take one of the enemy capital cities, the first side to achieve one of these two goals is proclaimed the winner.

The game has several dynamics: first is war strategy with movement of troops and historic ships of the conflict, second is political-diplomatic strategy to gain advantages in combat or other fields, and the third is a heroic dimension with different historical characters to chose from who modify the game mechanics, like Grau, Prat, Avaroa, Bolognesi, Baquedano, Pinto, among others.

The aim of the game is to contemplate this war from two centuries ago from a different perspective, with serenity and a playful-educational spirit. It's time to watch episodes of our history with the distance and reflection granted by time, without national animosities and at a table where friendship reigns.


Guerra en el Pacífico es un juego de mesa ambientado en el conflicto armado que entre 1879 y 1883 enfrentó a Perú, Bolivia y Chile, para 2, 3 o 4 jugadores de 8 años de edad en adelante. Existen dos bandos por los que se puede jugar: la alianza de Perú y Bolivia o Chile.

El objetivo del juego es lograr 10 puntos de victoria o tomar una de las capitales enemigas, quien logre primero una de esas dos metas se procalama vencedor.

El juego tiene varias dinámicas: la primera de estrategia bélica con movimiento de tropas y de los barcos históricos del conflicto, la segunda de estrategia político-diplomática para conseguir ventajas de combate o de otra clase, y la tercera una dimensión heroica, con diferentes personajes históricos a escoger que modifican la mecánica del juego, como Grau, Prat, Avaroa, Bolognesi, Baquedano, Pinto, entre otros.

El objetivo del juego es que contemplar la guerra de hace dos siglos desde un punto de vista distinto, con serenidad y espíritu lúdico-educativo. Es hora de ver episodios de nuestra historia con la distancia y reflexión que el tiempo otorga, sin animadversiones nacionales y en una mesa donde reine la camaradería.

item.description:
Skull King is a trick-taking game similar to 'Oh Hell!', 'Wizard', 'Eucher' and 'Spades', with players needing to state how many tricks they think they'll win each round. A unique element of this game is that bidding takes place simultaneously, leading to rounds that are sometimes over, or under-bid. As players must win the exact number of tricks that they bid to earn points, winning too many tricks is just as bad as winning too few and this leads to intense competition where losing a trick can be as exciting as winning one.

Skull King uses a 66-card deck that consists of five Escape cards, four suits numbered 1-13, five Pirate cards, 1 Tigress card, and 1 Skull King card. The game lasts ten rounds, and in each round, each player is dealt as many cards as the number of the round. All players simultaneously bid on the number of tricks they think they'll take by holding out a fist and on the count of three revealing a certain number of fingers (or possibly a closed fist for a bid of zero tricks).

Standard rules apply for the playing of cards, with one player leading off a card and other players following suit, if possible, and playing something else if not; however, a player may always choose to play one of the special, unnumbered cards — and the power of those cards might let you win a trick that otherwise would have gotten away. In more detail, the black Jolly Roger suit trumps the other three suits, a Mermaid trumps all numbered cards, a Pirate trumps the Mermaid, and the Skull King trumps everything — except if he appears in the same trick with a Mermaid, in which case she captures him and wins instead. An Escape card loses to any other card, and the Tigress card serves as either a pirate or escape card as desired by the player. Whoever wins a trick leads in the next trick.

If a player makes his bid exactly, he scores 20 points per trick; if he collects more or fewer tricks, he loses 10 points per trick he's off. If a player makes a bid of zero tricks, he wins points equal to ten times the current round number — but if he takes even a single trick, he loses this many points instead. If a player catches pirates with the Skull King, or the King with a mermaid, he scores bonus points. Whoever has the most points after ten rounds wins.

Additional cards were added in the 2018 to the Grandpa Beck's Games Skull King: Legendary Expansion edition of the game. The artwork was also given a complete refresh. This new version of the game replaces the previous version which will no longer be sold.

Summary of the new cards and rules in Skull King: Legendary Expansion, their inclusion is optional but they add a great deal of additional strategy and intrigue:

The Mermaids (2) beat any numbered card, but lose to any Pirate, with the exception of the Skull King, which can only be captured by a Mermaid.

The Loot Cards (2) function as Escape cards with a special twist: The player who captures a Loot card enters into an alliance with the player who played it down. If both get their bid correct for the round they are each awarded 20 bonus points.

The Kraken destroys any trick in which it is played, with no player winning the trick, regardless of the cards played in that trick.

New abilities have been granted to each of the 5 standard Pirate cards, granting them powers in line with those of the Tigress and the Skull King. Each Pirate's special ability is unlocked by winning a trick in which it is played and must be used immediately thereafter.

Rosie D'Laney: Choose any player to lead out the next trick, including yourself.
Bahij the Bandit: Draw 2 cards, then discard any 2 cards.
Rascal of Roatan: You may choose to wager 10 or 20 points. Win the points if you get your bid right, lose them if you get your bid wrong.
Juanita Jade: Look through all the cards not dealt that round.
Harry the Giant: You may choose to change your bid by +/- 1.

The expansion rules/score sheets also allow for flexible rounds. Players may choose to play the standard 10 rounds with an additional card dealt each round, or any other combination of cards/rounds. For example players can now choose to play 5 rounds with 10 cards dealt each round, or 8 rounds with 2,2,4,4,6,6,8 and 8 cards in a round, or 10 rounds with 5 cards dealt each round, whatever you'd prefer.

Reference cards, scoring summary cards, and bid reminder cards have also been added to the new Legendary Expansion version of the game to facilitate easier play for new players.

item.description:
"Welcome, girls and boys. My name is Rattlebones, and you have been cordially invited to spend the day at my Fabulous Festival of Dice! Play games! Win prizes! Ride the train! I'll be wandering about the park, and if you're the first one to find me, you win! Won't that be delightful?"

Rattlebones is a game about transforming dice. You start with standard six-sided dice, and throughout the course of the game you can remove sides and replace them with other sides that let you do all sorts of wonderful things. Every time you score points, you get closer to finding Rattlebones and, er, winning the game. Yes, winning! It's an experience to six-sided-die for!


Game Summary
Setup
- Place the Rattlebones meeple at 55, 60, or 65 VP space (for 2-4 players). Players each get 3 d6 (black, white, gray) -- basic d6 but the '1' is replaced by Rattlebones.
- Place random tiles on the empty spaces on the board.

Your Turn
Roll a die. May spend 1-2 gold to roll an extra 1-2 dice. Then, use each die one at a time:
- if Rattlebones shows, move Rattlebones back one space; game ends immediately if it hits a player score marker and most points wins.
- if pips or Rattlebones showing, move one of your pawns clockwise that many spaces (RB=1) and use the space you land on. Typically, you may add a die face matching that space to the die you used (replace any face except Rattlebones).
- otherwise, take whatever action the face allows (e.g., earn a stock marker or star token, which you may later turn in for VP; earn VP; steal stuff from other people; etc.).

item.description:
Break In is a push-your-luck card game in the vein of Incan Gold, with players trying to steal as many gems as possible from a bank before they get caught. The longer you stick around, the more you'll earn — but stay too long and you'll find yourself wearing handcuffs!

Break In — first published online in the game compilation "Femtitvå" — can be played with a standard deck of cards or with the free downloadable card deck provided online. To set up, remove the 7-10 in each suit from the deck. Shuffle the cards into three or four equal stacks, after which each player can look through one stack, then reshuffle that stack.

On a turn, a player draws the top card from a stack of her choice. If a face card shows up, it counts as a guard and is placed face-up on the table; any other card counts as cash and is placed in front of the player. (An ace also allows the player to look through one stack, then reshuffle it.) At any time during the round, a player can cash out, scoring one point for each pip on the cards in front of her and one point for each card face-up on the table, whether cash or guards.

If a second guard shows up in a suit, then the round ends and no one still in the round scores for the cash in front of them. After five rounds, whoever has the highest score wins.

Quests of Shadowgate is a 2-4 player card game based on the world of Shadowgate. Each player takes turns playing items from a shared adventure deck to help complete quests. Completing quests gives a player victory points based on which items were used to complete the quest. Once a player has amassed enough items to defeat the "Staff of Ages" quest, the game ends and the player with the most victory points wins.

This is a simple spin and move game where you begin your adventure from Uncle Hastus, follow the directions on the stops and should come back to Uncle first to win the game.

Complete game: 6 wooden game pieces, spinner, & box. The bottom of the box is the game board.

A wine testing trivia/word/memory game which includes a wine tasting element.

The game starts with the wine tasting part of the game. A blind wine tasting is performed and the players try to guess as many attributes of the wine as possible (Country, district, grape, year). With at least two correct answers you get a wine card.

From here the game is a roll and move game where you perform a task depending on which spot you land on.

Fun facts: The player reads a fun fact about wine, this player is rewarded with a wine card
Intermezzo: Good or bad things happen to the player. Follow the instructions on the card
Bubbly letters: Try to find the correct word from the scrambled words
Word rally: Make your team mates say four words
Picture memory: The team tries to memorize a picture for 30 seconds. The other team then give them a question about the picture

When one team have reached the end of the game track the team with the most wine cards is the winner.

Zombies vs. Wrestlers is the fourth game in the Army vs. Aliens series, with each game being playable on its own while also allowing for any faction in one game to be played against any faction in another or for multiple sets to be combined for team games or "last man standing" challenge matches.

As in the other games, Zombies vs. Wrestlers features two new asymmetric forces: zombies (lead by the necromancer) and wrestlers (lead by the Luchador). Each player takes one of the factions and rolls all nine dice. Taking turns, players then either attack the opponent or use a special power. Dice that are used are placed into the dice cup. If a player cannot attack or use a power, he instead "rallies", rolling the dice cup and simultaneously rerolling all of his dice still in play.

The zombie dice are unique in that they have no rank 4 unit, and instead have an additional rank 1 unit on their dice. However, they have several powers that revolve around gaining extra rank 1 units. The wrestlers have a more standard 123456 ranks, but have unique special powers involving "roll offs" and "tag team" plays.

The second game in the "AvA" series that started with Army vs. Aliens. It is a stand alone 2 player game, but can be combined with the other games in the series for variety or for larger games.

Each player takes one of the factions and rolls all 9 dice. Then players alternate either attacks or using a special power. Dice that are used are put back into the dice cup. If a player cannot attack or use a power, they instead 'rally' and roll the dice cup (and reroll any or all of their dice still in play).

The two forces have different special powers.

name.value: Panzer Grenadier: Korean War – Pusan Perimeter

item.description:
From publisher's website:

On June 25th, 1950, North Korean forces surged across the 38th Parallel into South Korea, starting what would become the Korean War. Within days the South Korean capital of Seoul had fallen and the Republic of Korea (ROK) Army had been routed. Remnants retreated southward and finally gathered around the port city of Pusan, where American troops had begun to arrive under the authority of the United Nations. Here on the Pusan Perimeter the U.N. forces would make their final stand.

Korean War - Pusan Perimeter is a complete boxed game in the Panzer Grenadier series based on these fearsome battles. You do not need any other game to play all of its 48 scenarios. Design is by Jay Townsend, creator of our Saipan game.

The North Koreans have a wide array of Soviet-made weapons, spearheading their attack with T-34/85 tanks. The South Koreans are fairly lightly equipped, while their American allies bring the tanks and guns that won the Second World War: M26 Pershings, M24 Chaffees and a blistering helping of air power.

The game includes four semi-rigid mapboards, with art by Guy Riessen. The maps are fully compatible with all others in the Panzer Grenadier series (and those from Panzer Grenadier (Modern) and Infantry Attacks, too). Plus 517 playing pieces: ultra-thick, scorchless, sootless laser-cut piece, a joy just to hold in your hands. And 48 scenarios.

name.value: Beatrix Potter's Peter Rabbit Race Game

item.description:
From the box -

A fun race game for all the family between Peter Rabbit, Squirrel Nutkin, Jemima Puddle Duck and Jeremy Fisher.

In the game each players (2-4) takes one of the famous Beatrix Potter characters from their starting square to the party being held in the woods (centre of the board), by throwing a die and moving the number of squares, drawing cards when indicated by the board with instructions (i.e Miss 1 Turn or have another go etc). First to the centre wins.

The object of the game is to reach West Point, the first player to do so wins the game. Players spin the dial and advance their counter as many spaces as the number spun.

If the counter rests upon a space with the picture of cannon on it, players follow the instructions: lose next turn, start over again, move up to next player, all players move one space forward, etc.

If it rests upon a space with a star, the player reads the meaning, which does not affect the game, such as: You will marry young and happy; You will become a great general etc.
Typical race spin and move game. The first player who travel from "Home" to "Commander in Chief" wins the game.

Triple Threat is a two-player micro strategy game set that includes three micro games: Better Gnomes and Gardens, Conquest of the Cosmos and Dragon's Dinner.

Better Gnomes and Gardens:
The greatest magazine known to gnome-kind, Better Gnomes and Gardens (BG&G), is about to announce the Gardener of the Year Award. That winner will be elevated to gnome celebrity status overnight if selected. And it just so happens that this year, the magazine will be judging gardens in your area of the kingdom.

Any gnome worth their garden hoe knows that only fairy dust will grow the best flowers. For years, you and your partner have found the perfect spot where the little winged dandruff-sufferers fly. However, with the contest looming, the magical gloves are off between you two. You’ll use your spells to rearrange the garden a bit. Hey, you can’t help it if your flowers happen to be the only ones under the oncoming flying fertilizers. As they say, "That’s just how the seedling sprouts."

The goal of Better Gnomes and Gardens is to maneuver your Flower cards into the path of oncoming fairies and earn the most points.

Conquest of the Cosmos:
Space, a word that means lots of nothing. Your mission is to seek out five points of planetary goodness. To destroy civilizations and others that get in your way. To boldly go and say, "This is mine!"

The goal of Conquest of the Cosmos is to be the first to earn 5 points by outmaneuvering your opponent and conquering planets.

Dragon's Dinner:
For centuries the Elder Dragons have been telling younger generations not to play with their food, but you and your friend want to challenge that. To your surprise, there is so much your food can do. You can keep decorative trophies or intimidate your food in to doing things for you. Sure you could just chomp them down to restore your strength, but it’s so much better to be entertained. Now fun is what’s for dinner.

The goal of Dragon's Dinner is to To collect the most Trophy points from your meal(s).

Today is the groundbreaking ceremony! Full of beans, the frog, rabbit, beaver and hamster want to build houses of different heights. It doesn't matter whether the buildings end up a little unsteady as long as no two floors are identical. If you decide to stop drawing cards at the right moment, you will be the happy winner in the end.

In Biberbau & Co., players have to construct a house with two floors (for the frog), three floors (rabbit), four floors (beaver), and one with one to five floors for the hamster. They take turns drawing cards — which represent levels of a building — deciding after each draw whether to finish the house with the current number of levels for the specific kind of animal or continue drawing to go for a higher house worth more points in the end. If they draw two identical levels, however, the building is forfeited and their turn is over.

item.description:
The rules from two authentic ancient Egyptian games, Senet and The Palm Tree Game, form the basis of this game. The track comes from a wall painting from a tomb in Thebes. The pawns mimic the escape of slaves from the garden.

The players are the slaves who try to escape the garden of Amon. The game consist of two phases. During the day phase the players run through the garden, obtaining Fate Cards along the road. When a player reaches the resting place with his 5 pawns, the night phase starts. The players now race for the boat at the end of the vineyard. The first player who gets his 5 pawns on the boat wins the game. Fate cards, who resemble various Egyptian gods can help you or hinder you... The gods are unpredictable!

Moving your pawns doesn't require any dice: the game uses Throwing Sticks ('Djebao' or 'Fingers'), just like in the old Senet game.

VludKin ClaNz is a card game for two players about the struggle of the VludKin for control over the Vlud, the energy upon which their world is built. Each player starts with two VludKin cards from different ClaNz, and their goal is to not have the lowest influence VludKin when the game ends, and therefore be the player controlling the Vlud.

This is an original "stack-building" card game for two players, with a set of rules that are quick and simple to learn, but offering numerous strategic options and dirty tricks on the path to victory.

Each player receives two random VludKin cards from different ClaNz, and during the game they draw a card from the central deck which they then try to win with one of their VludKin, rolling over that VludKin's Influence modified by the card. If this card is an Influence card, they can then place it under one of the VludKin, altering their Influence value based on the Clan type shown on the card. If it's a Power card, then they can carry out the special action on that card before it is discarded.

Failing to win a card will earn the VludKin a -1 Influence token to their total, and they can get rid of these only through trading an Influence card matching their Clan or the use of certain power cards, which might actually move all the tokens to an enemy instead. If an Influence card is failed, then the other player gets a chance to win it. If a Power card is failed, then the power is automatically played by the enemy VludKin opposite; sometimes it's in your advantage to fail a Power card...

During the game, the stacks of cards under each VludKin are built, changing their Influence up and down over turns until the game ends and the player with the lowest VludKin loses. With the ability to play Influence cards on the other player's VludKin and with the use of Power cards to move Influence cards around the stacks, a level of strategy is added to the simple core rules.

The game ends when either a VludKin reaches ten Influence or the central deck is empty, so through the use of Influence and Power cards a tense game builds in which the balance of Influence can change right up to the end on the asymmetrical board game playfield. There is little down time for the players and no hidden hands of cards, so this provides an exciting head-to-head experience.

VludKin ClaNz comes with eight VludKin from four ClaNz, two copies of each of the twelve different power cards, and forty Influence cards. Adding extra sets of the Power and Influence cards gives you the option to customize the central deck to how you want to play, and also gives the option for a longer game.

Can you gain influence over the VludKin in this original card game?

Hunt and Seek™ Young Xpert is for youngsters who love challenges. Like the other games in the series, this game develops a child’s reactions, sense of observation, visual acuity and concentration. Numbers written in French and English allow children to learn the basics of reading a second language. Different levels in the game add to the challenge.

The aim of the game is to find 50 objects hidden in the beautifully illustrated game boards. Other challenges face players who may try to locate the little mouse found in different locations on the game boards or find the six mystery characters.

Psycho-Slasher: The Game is a 30-page miniatures game homage to the low budget slasher films of the 1970's and 1980's, playable in any scale from 15mm to 54mm.

Psycho-Slasher is easy to learn, and fun to play, with each player acting as a Writer and running their own Slasher. The competing Slashers don't interact directly, but the Writers have the ability to hinder or help other Slashers with the placement of new weapons, or, more importantly, manipulating the horde of Pawns (Victims) that populate the Slasher film tableau.

You say that you love the idea, but that you don't have miniatures for a game like this? No problem! Included with the game are printable paper miniatures... you get 5 distinct Slashers, a Cop, and 4 distinct Pawns. Print as many Pawns and Cops as you need, snip, fold, glue, and you are all set! Also included are printable Weapon counters, and Pawn Special counters that introduce twists to the game like Phones (self-explanatory,) Beer (dangerous for Pawns), and Hysteria (AHHHHH!!!).

Whenever a Slasher ends his/her movement in contact with a Pawn or Cop, the Slasher must conduct an attack. If the Attack is successful your Slasher removes the Pawn from the board, earning Collection Points.

Collection Points translate into ratings, or popularity, for the Writer’s Slasher and Slasher story line. So, earning Collection Points in the game, while preventing rival Slashers from collecting points when you can, is how you can win the game.

Not recommended for children under the age of 16. This is meant to be a fun game, based on a movie genre, and does not take itself seriously... still, the subject matter may not be appropriate for everyone.

In Drag Ball: The Game, players play as one of twelve drag queens, developing her skills throughout the game to try to outlast the competition to win the crown. You need to be the one with the most sass, sophistication and aesthetic to reign victorious.

Drag Ball: The Game plays in fast-paced rounds, with one player being eliminated each round. Each round consists of a mini-challenge, a main challenge, a runway look construction, critiques in which players are ranked, and finally the "fish or filth" phase when the bottom two players face off to see who continues in the game. In addition to managing their hand of cards and creating a cohesive runway look, players will compete in small physical challenges such as lip-syncing in order to gain advantages in that round.

item.description:
Les Guerres de Bourgogne 1474-1477 (Wars of Burgundy) is a historical simulation from October 1474 to January 1477. One player plays the role of the Burgundian armies and their allies (Duchy of Savoy and Italian states), led by the famous Duke Charles the Bold, and the other player is in command of the Swiss Confederacy and its allies (Duchy of Lorraine and German states). The objectives are to take control of the Savoy and Lorraine territories, win pitched battles or major sieges, and neutralise the opponent's allies.

This is both a strategic & tactical game with armies and garrisons evolving on the main strategic map and units fighting on a tactical map featuring a typical XVth century battleground. Units are men-at-arms, pikes, bowmen, crossbowmen, halberdiers, hangunners, and early cannons, from 2,000 men at full strength, 1,000 horsemen or 200 cannons of all calibers. The "chrome" of that period is added with tactical chits (charge, harassment shots, raining arrows, ditch, fence, clash of pikes, cannon battery) and events such as rain, snow, minor ally, no fight or betrayal, no wing deployment. Optional rule includes a possible intervention of the French kingdom to support one side or the other. You will be able to fight the famous battles of Hericourt (1474), Grandson & Morat (1476), and Nancy (1477), the latter involving a fatal outcome for Charles the Bold.

The complete sequence of a turn:
I/ Burgundy
1) Reinforcement, replacement
2) strategic move
3) attrition phase
4) combat phase (battles & sieges)
II/ Swiss Confederacy
Same sequence
III/ Diplomatic phase
check for victory

The game includes 108 die-cut counters, an A3 size strategic and an A5 size tactical map. One 6 sided die is necessary.

name.value: Bear vs Gorilla vs CEO vs Hippie

item.description: Bear vs Gorilla vs CEO vs Hippie is a fast-paced card game in which players choose a random character, get some cards and chips, then attack other players to try to win their chips, knocking other players out when their chip supply vanishes. The last player standing wins!

link.value: Bear vs Gorilla vs CEO vs Hippie: Extra Things

item.description:
Pure Halloween is a strategy game for two players in which the player who first occupies all nine regions of the Sudoku-type game board wins.

Players control a "team" of Halloween figures, with each figure having a unique way of moving. The rules are simple and easy to learn, but winning the game requires complex strategic maneuvers and well-planned tactics.

"During the earlier days of firefighting, volunteer fire brigades used deception to compete with one another in order to be the first responders on scene, and subsequently receive payment from the property owner's insurance.

Fire Call positions you at the front lines of modern-day firefighting with a heated twist reminiscent of the combative early years. As you battle opposing fire departments, pull out all the stops to gain control of the most districts by collecting equipment, sabotaging opponents, and successfully completing fire calls to win the game."

The game objective is to become the Fire Department (player) with the most occupied districts by collecting and using the necessary equipment to complete Fire Calls. Once all the districts are covered, the Fire Department with the most occupied districts wins the game.

On their turn, players roll the die and move their markers along the track. The space they land on can have one of a number of effects. Players may gain fire equipment, have the opportunity to complete a fire call and occupy a district, gain cards for special effects later or sustain on-the-job injuries and be put in hospital. Players will also gain ranks throughout the game, starting off as Firefighters and being promoted up to Fire Chief.

When fire calls are completed by players, the corresponding district is covered and occupied. Immediately after all 11 districts are occupied, the game ends and the player with the most wins.

QuickWits is a fast-paced card game based on naming items within certain categories and descriptions. The game is very similar to Anomia, but the content is more mature in theme.

During the game, players take turn drawing a card and placing it in front of them. Each card has one of six different symbols on it, and when two players have the same symbol on the card on the top of their pile, they face off. Each player has to name something in his opponent's card category before his opponent names something in the category on his own card. The fastest player takes his opponent's card and places it face down in his score pile.

The game ends once all the cards have been dealt, and the player with the most cards in his pile wins.

item.description:
In the family-friendly game Kampen om Fredriksten, players are merchant families in the city Halden in southern Norway during the 17th century. Players run their businesses and try to adapt to the events of the period, all while helping building the fort Fredriksten, which will protect the city from repeated attacks from the Swedish king, Karl XII.

Each round, you roll your dice and use them to activate your buildings. Each building can only be activated by a certain die value, and will provide money, construction material, soldiers, or victory points. If you erect buildings with different dice values, you will be able to utilize your dice most efficiently. Also, you can customize your buildings according to your needs by upgrading them with different combinations of cards, increasing or changing their production, or changing their required dice value. Contribute to the building of Fredriksten to receive extra resources, and make sure to have your private army ready when Karl XII attacks.

item.description:
Everyone is a winner, because by playing this game you broaden the knowledge for traffic rules!

In FÆRDSELS TEORI your purpose is to answer questions correctly and gather the four tokens: Orange, Blue, White and Black.

There are four large fields (one in each corner) where you will get a token for correct answers.

From the center to the corners there are fields divided into Red, Yellow and Green.
If you land on RED your turn is over.
If you land on GREEN you can roll the die again.
If you land on YELLOW you will have to reply a question: Wrong answer will end your turn, a right answer will give you another go.

The winner is the one who got all four tokens AND returned back to Start where (s)he will have to answer correctly on FOUR out of SIX questions.

Set in the Golden Age of organized crime, players head rival crime families attempting to gain control of organized crime in the city. In the vein of Citadels, deceive your opponents and deduce their strategy as you gain wealth and respect in your rise to power. Plot and alter your own strategy as the game unfolds and as fortunes change hands quickly and unexpectedly.

Each round, players select characters through a secret draft. After all players have selected a character, they take their turns in order depending on the character they have chosen.

In the first part of each player's turn, they will use their character's tactic to their advantage to either earn cash, to take cash from their opponents, or to derail their opponent's progress in some way. Each character has his own unique tactic. As the game progresses, bluffing and deduction become increasingly important to gain an advantage over your opponents.

In the second part of the player's turn, each will have a choice of three different illegal operations to perform, and may perform any one of the three before ending their turn.

The first player to reach the required level of respect wins the game.

Battle Market is one part financial management game and one part fight to the death. You go around the board buying property and paying rent. Along the way, each property you control grants you a special power. Most of these special powers are useful for attacking your rivals. Unlike most games in this genre, the ultimate goal isn't to bankrupt the other players, but to kill them.

Players are trying to find the golden helmet, which was buried with a mighty man centuries ago in the area of municipality of Lieto. They travel around Lieto and the player who is the first to find the helmet is the winner.

Game play is simple roll and move, the helmet is always in the same location. There are some other locations along the track, where players might get a free roll or lose a turn. About one fourth before the goal it is possible to choose from three different paths.

The game is basically an advertisement of the Lieto.

Players are citizens of Turku and their mission is to show the city for tourists. They need to move through several sightseeing places and then end in the railway station to finish their mission. First one to complete the round is the winner.

The play area is a stylized map of Turku with several different routes around the city. Players move by rolling a die. Some of the locations are marked with red, and on those locations something special happens and players refer the rulebook.

The game is most likely a fundraiser, several local companies are shown on the map and the special locations have references to them.

Hexopolis is a fast-paced, intense strategy card game that includes tactical elements thanks to a dynamic board and zombies controlled by all players. Expect to be kept on your toes with cutthroat moves and counter-moves.

The game is won and lost by activating ingredients on the table; two different ones to win, two identical ones to lose.

Players start by creating the board from a set of hexagonal tiles around a tile marked as the Altar set in the middle of the table. Then, they draw five cards and play their move in turns.

The different actions from the cards include summoning zombies, moving them to specific tiles to bring ingredient cards from one's hand to the table, or sacrifice zombies on the Altar tile to activate or deactivate ingredients already on the table.
Cards can also be combined into advanced actions that bend the rules (steal cards, cancel actions, etc.).

Rules are in English and French. Cards are bilingual.

Comes as a printed-on-demand box or as a PDF file.

Each player has a 3x3 board that he randomly fills with tiles, which have parts of words. The rest of the tiles are shuffled and one of them is turned face-up.

Players try to make a word matching the tile to one or more of their tiles on the board. The fastest one takes the tile and removes the used tiles from his board. The one who clears the board first is the winner.

POOCH: "A New Exciting Game of Dogs That Try To Outsmart The Ever Watchful Dog Catcher"

Dogs have wandered far from their homes and kennels, and now try to get back without being caught by the dog catcher.

Game includes a blow-molded plastic base, four plastic dog tokens, a dog catcher truck, and a spinner.

Game description from the publisher:

The riffin', the loudness, the drinks, the girls, the songs, the lyrics, the fights, the fuck-ups and the wins, plus much, much more...

The Rock Science Motörhead Game includes 1,600 questions on the band's history from Lemmy's first steps into rock 'n' roll to the awakening of the monster that Motörhead is today. Round up your friends and play the loudest trivia game in the world. Three levels of difficulty — Poser, Fan and Scientist — and tense betting means that the novice can give the hardcore fan a fair fight.

Flickin' Cars With Guns is a tabletop dexterity game for 2 or more players playable in as little as 10 minutes. Players use diecast toy cars (like Hot Wheels or Matchbox) to represent armed vehicles. The goal is to destroy your opponents by shooting and crashing into them.

The game is meant to be played on a standard kitchen table, and you can use household items as obstacles and terrain. A 4'x3' table littered with plates, cups, and bowls is pretty standard. In fact playing a quick game after dinner, before cleaning up the table, is one of the funnest approaches.

Each turn the player "flicks" their car twice and shoots once. The act of flicking is where the physical skill and challenge of the game come in. Crashing into an obstacle hurts your car, and accidentally flicking off the table is penalized as well, so players have to be careful.

Shooting is done by rolling 2D6 with a to-hit target number equal to the number of inches to your target. So if your opponent is 8" away you need 8+ to hit. Double damage on double 6s, and shots always miss on double 1s.

There are several variants and optional rules that can be bolted onto this core system, such as droppable weapons, demolition derby mode, a drinking game, stunt bonuses, power ups, using playing cards, etc. to ensure plenty of longevity and suitability for all types of players.

Bordello d'Oriente is an adult card game where each player plays the role of a pimp and manages his girls making them gain money and fight against the opponents' babies. The goal is to defeat the opponents maneuvering his call girls with the limits and abilities dictated by the board.

There are four kind of girls: escorts, street hookers, young hopefuls and, new in Bordello d'Oriente and not found in Squillo, geishas, asian girls with new power and abilities. Each girl has her own peculiarities, parcel and can be equipped with a wilde array of items and "pimped up" with power-ups.

Bordello d'Oriente can be played without Squillo or can be used to extend it with its 100 and more new cards (girls, power-ups, events and the brand new "trap cards"). The game also includes six guest cards drawn by guest artists.

link.value: Squillo Time Travels: Satiri e Baccanti

item.description:
Card game of the Roman Empire in the second half of the third century AD, a fifty-year period during which the average reign of an emperor was a mere 2.5 years.

Each player controls a number of imperial candidates whom they try to push to the top position to gain honor and prestige by solving some of Rome's many crises -- invasions by Goths, Persians and Palymrans plus the incessant demands of the populace -- before quickly yielding to the next emperor.

In a system reminiscent of King's Breakfast, players draft influence cards which they may later deploy to help them win top jobs in the empire or secretly use against opponents to make existing crises more difficult to handle. To gain power players must commit cards sufficient to outpoll the opposition and solve crises, but must avoid overcommitment that reduces future options and opportunities. In addition, each candidate has a different special ability which must be reckoned with.

At the end of play the player with the most prestige points wins.

Game description from the publisher:

"Australian troops had, at Milne Bay in New Guinea, inflicted on the Japanese their first undoubted defeat on land. Some of us may forget that of all the Allies it was the Australian soldiers who first broke the spell of the invincibility of the Japanese Army." —Field Marshall Sir William Slim

Defeated at sea in the battle of the Coral Sea in May and then distracted by the US Marine Corps landings on Guadalcanal, the Japanese High Command was forced to change its plans for New Guinea. After diverting the previously allocated Army regiment to reinforce Guadacanal, it fell to the Navy to gather a scratch force to capture the "lightly defended" airfield on the eastern tip of New Guinea.

Unfortunately for Japanese plans, those months of delays allowed Australia to finish assembling a brigade of Militia at Milne Bay during July, then rush a veteran AIF brigade there shortly before the Japanese landings commenced on August 25th, 1942.

Several scenarios are included in Milne Bay to allow players to explore different Australian and Japanese plans.

Grid-Hammer is a tabletop game for 2 to 4 players that's played on a 9x9 square board called the "Grid". The object of the game is to move any one of your ten pieces across the Grid and past your opponents' defenses, then exit with this piece off the opposite side of the board.

Pieces move, climb, rotate, capture, transform, and combine into new hybrid pieces as they surge across the board and off the Grid.

Grid-Hammer is themed on the Grid itself. What would an ecosystem populated by grid creatures look like?

name.value: Mise en Place: The Culinary Knowledge Game

item.description: Mise en Place: The Culinary Knowledge Game is a fun and educational game designed to be played by up to six players or teams. Players are immersed in a restaurant environment where they encounter nearly 1200 questions based on culinary terms and concepts. Players begin as entry-level employees and are prompted to answer questions in each of the six certification areas in order to be promoted to Apprentice, Sous Chef, and finally to Executive Chef to win the game. Along the path to promotion, players encounter tally it up questions on measurements, recipe conversions, and the use of fractions and percentages.

item.description:
Battle Mice is a near-perfect information card game for two players.

The deck consists of three identical sets of mice numbered 1–8. Each player receives one deck, then the last "neutral" deck is shuffled, two of those cards are put aside, and the rest dealt three to each player. Each player then places his first eight mice in a 3x3 grid with the middle square left empty. The neutral mice are kept as a hand of cards.

On a player's turn, he can move one mouse one step. A mouse that moves into the middle empty square has escaped, and the opponent's mouse with the same number is defeated (turned over). Each mouse has a special ability that affects only the two adjacent mice; for example, the fighter mouse protects the adjacent mice from being defeated, the nurse mouse heals a defeated mouse, the speed mouse allows adjacent mice to move twice, and so on. Each time a mouse exits, the active player can place a neutral mouse from his hand on one of the corner squares, if available.

At the end of the game, players receive one point per escaped mouse, but some of the mice give an extra bonus depending on the order in which they escaped. This order is determined by the two neutral mice set aside at the start of the game.

GötzenDiener is a quick set-collecting card game.

The deck consists of five types of cards representing objects of worship, numbered 1–5, of various quantities. On a player's turn, he picks a card, then either keeps it or sends it to another player who cannot refuse the card. If a player gets a hand of four cards, he must discard all cards of any one type from his hand, applying the effect on those card(s).

The game ends when either the deck runs out, someone has a hand of three identical cards, or someone discards a 5. All players then show their hands, earning points for the most common object of worship in hand and the runner-up, and being penalized for everything else, those objects being heretical symbols.

In Cavern Crawl, players take on the role of one of 4 adventurers to explore the caverns, fight monsters and collect loot. It can be played either cooperatively or competitively.

Players start on the same "Start" card, and have slightly different attack, search and defense abilities depending on their character. On their turn, they first draw a map card and connect it to the already placed cards, expanding the caverns and creating more opportunities for battles and loot.

Combat and gaining coins works through dice rolls. Players have to beat certain defence scores of the enemies in their roll, and they gain the associated rewards if they're successful. This can also include treasure cards which provide bonuses and extra abilities.

Players can pool their dice rolls together if they are on the same space, to make it easier to gain rewards or defeat monsters. In this case, the rewards are split.

Players can also attack each other for the chance to steal coins from their opponents.

The goal of the game is to be the first to find 10 coins and make it back to the entrance. Each character has an additional secondary objective which provides an alternative winning condition.

Fisherman's Profit is a simple bluffing "outsmart the others" card game based on the Japanese proverb "If snipe and seashell fight, the fisherman profits", meaning that if two struggle, a third party wins.

From a deck of either blue or red seashells of different values, three cards are placed face down on the play area, and in turn, players peek at the unoccupied seashells, then place either a fisherman or a snipe on one of them. When all have placed, the seashells are turned up and resolved: Blue seashells can be taken only by snipes, and red only by the fishermen. If two have placed on the same, the latter will steal a previously claimed seashell from the former — but if both fisherman and snipe are on the same seashell, the fisherman profits according to the old proverb and both gets the seashell and catches the bird.

User summary:

A simple he-thinks-that-I-think card game.

Players have a set of cards numbered 1–6, where 6 is the king and 1 is a simple pawn. The back of each card is the Pariah, which is zero.
Each turn, players roll a die each and may play face down any card of that number or lower. All turned face up, and you count number of wins. The King wins over all cards except the fool (2), all other cards win over the fool. If a player has played a card higher than the number he rolled, he cannot turn the card, and it's a Pariah, which loses to all. Each win is awarded 1 point.

Every card has a special power, that usually affects his ability to play next turn. For example, the Pariah allows the player to not roll the die, but choose die result for the next turn.

This is repeated for 5 rounds, which counts as one hand. The player with most points after three hands wins the game.

User summary:

A solitaire card game based on the concept of rhythmic video games.

The player has a band of five dancers from a selection of 11, numbered 1–5. The dancers are put in a line, where each dancer is either in the front row or back row. From a shuffled deck of notes also numbered 1–5, five cards are lined up. Each turn, the cards of the lest represented colour will "fall down" (are slid down a bit) and must be "caught" by the team of dancers. However, in order to achieve a "perfect rhythm", a note must be caught by a dancer with the same number, if caught by a dancer with a number at most 1 more or less than the note is "good" if the note and the dancer are of the same colour; anything else is a "fail".
Before each catch, the player can only move one dancer one step, either from back row to front row, or sideways, in which case they swap places with whoever was beside them. However, moving sideways to a spot where no dancer is is not counted as a move, and will also cause the dancer who now ends up in the same column as the moved one, to move in the opposite direction, a so-called "cross move".

Being in the back row gives the dancer one extra turn to catch the note. Also, apart from the current row of falling notes, the player will have another row of notes above it, enabling the player to plan his moves one turn ahead.

The final score is decided by the number of perfects and good rhythm catches. Also, before each game, the player chooses which song to dance to; each song having a special effect on the game. Each dancer also has a special power to activate once per game.

The Ravens of Thri Sahashri is a two-player cooperative card game. One player is playing the girl Ren who has lost her memory; the other is the detective trying to repair it. The game is about trying to communicate as well as possible by simply the choice of cards. (Note: "Thri Sahashri" is the buddhist term for a trillion worlds combined, which in this case means "the other plane".)

Of a deck consisting of cards of five colors and numbered 1–5, the Ren player draws four cards and keeps them face down. The goal for both players is to ensure that when the hand ends, the playing field has cards of these colors and these colors only.

Each round, the detective draws as many cards as he wishes from the shuffled deck, putting them on the playing field according to the marks on the cards. The deck also contains ravens, which when drawn will "eat" any discarded cards of that color and threaten to take them out of the game.

When the detective player is done, the Ren player picks one of the cards in the playing field and puts on the leftmost still "incomplete" hidden card. A hidden card is complete when that card plus the cards placed on it total 7. (The fourth pile, however, should total only 5, according to the Japanese poem metric "dodoitsu" that goes 7-7-7-5.)

Once all four hidden cards are completed, the round ends and unless the playing field has exactly the colors represented among the hidden cards, the players have failed. The game is played for three hands, but in the final hand, one hidden card must be completed per round, lest the players fail. Players also fail if the deck runs out or if all five Ravens are drawn.

item.description:
COGZ is a mad scientist strategy board game set in the steampunk era, where someone has broken the mad professor’s chromatic cogtraption!
 You are a cognizant cogineer trying to repair the broken cogtraption before the professor returns. The other cogineers all seem to think they have the superior cognition needed to rebuild the chromatic device. It’s time to prove you are the true cogineer genius!
Hurry! You recognise there isn’t much time to do this incognito before the professor returns with his cog-nac…


				
					How to Play

Cogineers are all swapping segments of the broken cogtraption to repair it. As long as the segment is different, cogineers gain cognition (game points) for doing so. When a mechanism is repaired fully it can no longer be modified by the other cogineers who all have their own agenda for repairs. There is bonus cognition and bonus turns to be awarded for clever repairs as well.

COGZ is a very simple game though it hides a huge amount of strategic depth which is normally discovered as cogineers gain experience. The best way to learn the game is to play the game. You can download the latest rules from the website (http://cogz.raez.net) and if you signup to the Newsletter you can also get the download link for the print and play version.


				
					Game Play Features


 Mensa Endorsed - COGZ has been tested by Mensa Members from a number of countries and has been endorsed by the High IQ Society Mensa.
 Colour Blind Accessible - COGZ has been heavily tested with Colour Blind people with various visual impairments and optimised to be accessible to the common colour blind limitations.
 Variants Included



 COGZ included a book of variants. Tournaments, Team play, Different board layouts, 3D board setups and increase player range from 1-12 players.



 Free Shipping - COGZ has free shipping to any international destination. It will also include VAT in Europe and GST in Australia.
 Multiple Languages - COGZ has been translated into multiple languages. The latest rules can be downloaded from the website download section when they are complete.



 Play Tested - COGZ has been play tested for almost 3 years and the game play has been repeatedly improved.
 Wide Age - Both kids and adults can play COGZ and learn new skills and strategies as they progress.
 Wide Skill - COGZ can be played very lightly right through to intense strategic planning.
 Improve IQ - The more you play COGZ the better your pattern matching, planning and strategy will become.
 Modular - The broken cogtraption is constructed from the Cog Tiles and provides infinite variations.
 Elegant - The COGZ rules have been refined repeatedly to be as polished as a nice brass cog.
 Competitive - In 2 or 3 players, COGZ can be incredibly strategic. COGZ Tournament variant is included.
 Casual - In higher numbers of players (5 and 6), COGZ is more casual and social fun.
 Simple - There are numerous layers of strategy in COGZ making it simple to learn but hard to master.



				
					Game Component Features


 1200dpi graphics
 thick cardboard
 linen finish on all components
 cotton drawstring bag
 foil logo printing on Drawstring bag
 solid brass game gadget interscrews
 game gadget functional gear mechanisms



COGZ will be available primarily via the RAEZ Shop shop.RAEZ.net and your favourite retail store.

item.description:
D.D. Dogma is a party-style card game simulating the back-and-forth dialogue between roleplayers and the game master in an RPG session.

Each player selects a team of heroes from the available line-up, then receives six quest cards and a number of play cards that signify dice numbers.

Taking turns, players ask an opponent for a quest; that player unveils one of his quests, then the asking player tries to solve the quest by rolling as many dice as he has heroes, activating their abilities to generate resources such as "battle", "magic", "thievery" and so on. Each quest has its own clear requirements, and if the player manages to generate the correct resources, he gains the victory points the quest generates; if not, these points go to the quest owner.

After the dice roll, players can adjust the values of the dice by playing cards from their hands, either elevating, lowering or re-rolling the dice rolled. After this is done, the dice are applied to the lineup of heroes, activating different abilities.

For the first time, a game about Marshall amps. Explore the exciting life of Jim Marshall as the Father of Loud, a great musician and champion engineer.

The only Marshall trivia game. 50 years of rock history. A tribute to the gods of riffs.

The loudest rock game ever.


1,600 trivia questions ranging from early rock and metal to current artists. All questions have three levels of difficulty: Poser, Fan and Scientist. All players are always involved since they bet on each other’s rock knowledge.

The goal is to be the first to finish one lap around the board through the use of rock knowledge, clever betting and a bit of luck. Players answer questions about anecdotes, myths, rockers, albums, songs and Sex, Amps & Rock ‘n’ Roll. You can also be asked to hum the riffs of well-known rock songs.

Features:

Authentic Rock Science Marshall Tortex game paws by DUNLOP, made exclusively for this game.

Inspired by the classic Marshall look of the 50th anniversary amps, the game even has its own Marshall model number.

Exclusive limited edition poster, Rock Science Marshall picks and Marshall stack card holders, found only in this game.

In the world of computer programming, there can only be one winner - either zeros or ones!

One Zero One is an abstract strategy card game for two players. With identical 16-card decks, each player (as either 0 or 1) plays cards to the program display, endeavouring to gain control of lines of program code. Each line is worth a set number of points. As soon as the program runs, points are tallied and the winner is determined.

Most cards display commands which will affect the cards already in play. The order and position of cards played by each opponent will have a huge bearing on the outcome, as will the ability of the players to adjust their strategies as the programming code changes.

Game #1 in 'The Mike Line' of games from Grail Games.
